Award.AwardTitle: II-NEW: Experimental Characterization and CAD Development Testbed for Nanoscale Integrated Circuits

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this NSF CRI-II-NEW project is to develop a testbed for computer aided design (CAD) simulations, experimental metrology, and software and hardware calibrations to support cross-layer evaluation of novel nanoscale 3D heterogeneous integration of CMOS and post-CMOS technologies. Proposed tools and equipment acquisitions and sustainment will allow bottom-up evaluations from materials, fundamental physics, and experimental metrology to device and circuits to large-scale systems. The proposed infrastructure is unique and will enable thorough evaluation of new 3D heterogeneous integration concepts with accuracy only parallel to full-scale experimental prototyping. It will directly impact the nano-electromagnetics, nano-device, circuits, 3D IC and manufacturing research directions, and will also have significant impact on the big data analytics, renewable energy, smart-city, RF and electromagnetics research initiatives in Computer Science and Electrical Engineering (CSEE) department at University of Missouri-Kansas City (UMKC). The testbed will not only facilitate transformative research, but will also allow broad ranging educational and outreach activities such as new undergraduate and graduate curriculum development with lab modules, training and mentoring of research students, research dissemination thorough forums and seminars, development of online repositories and online labs, and nanotechnology awareness for K-12 students through summer workshops. The boarder impact of this project is that the proposed infrastructure will provide unique opportunities for research, education and community outreach in the fields of nanomaterials, nanodevice, nanocircuit, biosensing, heterogonous integration, and nanomanufacturing.

The research focus of this collaborative project will be to develop nanoscale heterogeneous 3D integration and testing framework for bio-sensing and computing applications leveraging novel materials, devices, circuits and integration schemes. 3D integration provides opportunities to realize systems with heterogeneous layers, such as bio-analytical device and mixed-signal information processing layers that can be vertically stacked and electrically connected through dense vias. However, such implementation with CMOS is challenging due to CMOS?s scaling limits, noise coupling between dissimilar analog and digital circuit components and limitations of die-die or layer-layer stacking. We propose a new 3-D heterogeneous integration approach that overcomes challenges by utilizing new materials such as Carbon Nanotube, MoS2, and nanoscale geometry to realize highly sensitive bio-sensors for bio-molecule detections, scalable 2-D material based ultra-low power devices that exhibit FET like switching and Negative Differential Resistance (NDR) for seamless integration of signal processing and logic components, and monolithic 3-D integration techniques with dense vias. Initial projections reveal significant benefits for such heterogeneous integration over conventional 2-D CMOS based multi-chip based approaches. If realized, this can be game-changing for mixed-signal ASICs, and as well for bio-medical applications such as point-of-care and lab-on-a-chips.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: We proposed to develop new infrastructure for computer aided design (CAD) simulations, experimental metrology, and software and hardware calibrations to support cross-layer evaluation of novel nanoscale 3-D Integrated Circuits for beyond CMOS, heterogeoneous 3-D integration for ambient intelligence, and nanoscale sensor technologies for nanocomposites, and health-care applications.

Outcomes: The award enabled us to acquire a set of new equipment including ultra-high resolution Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM), probe station and eight micromanipulators, five workstations, two customized high-end servers, and several portable measurement and calibration devices. Additionally, we added several software and CAD packages from COMSOL, Cadence, Mentor Graphics and Synopsys. These resources helped us conduct experiment and simulation on various materials, devices, circuits, interconnects and large-scale architectures for diverse applications. The testbed spurred research activities in the three major research directions: 3-D IC, ultra-low power device and heterogeneous integration, and nanoscale sensors. Traditional EDA tools are designed for 2-D ICs. Leveraging the testbed facilities, we developed a method to leverage the existing tool chain to design and evaluate 3-D ICs. We have developed an approach to design and analyze nanosensors in free space or in more complex multi-layer environments. In many cases, the developed nanosensors are buried inside a composite to create a smart self-sensing material. The matrix or the dielectric slab where the nanosensor is embedded typically has dimensions that are several thousand times larger than the nanosensor itself.  Commercial full-wave software packages can explicitly model such topologies, but due to the multiscale nature of the problem, an extremely large number of discretization elements is necessary which in turn demands prohibitive computational times. Therefore, we developed an accurate and highly accelerated electromagnetic solver for carbon nanotubes (CNTs) buried in a lossy dielectric slab based on the multi-layer Green?s function approach. To address the power management and thermal stress in high-density and high-performance integrated circuits we have developed couple of circuit design techniques for on-chip power gating and voltage regulation.

 

The hardware and software resources also helped the PIs and their collaborators develop many other discipline-specific and interdisciplinary research and curricular initiatives in the areas of next generation computing, sensing, big data analytics, bio-informatics, renewable energy, electromagnetics, and green and connected city. A major achievement during this award period is the final planning and start of the construction for first ever cleanroom in University of Missouri Kansas City to house the proposed Center for Interdisciplinary Nanotechnology Research (CINTR), which was initiated by this NSF CRI grant. The proposed CINTR is expected to become the regional hub for collaborative and multidisciplinary research on the applications of nanotechnologies for computing, communication, energy, biomedical and agricultural sectors. A 2000sqft space is allocated and the planning for cleanroom was completed. The construction of the cleanroom will be complete by July 2020. This project had a direct impact on the cleanroom construction. The projects and collaborative efforts that utilized the resources provided by this grant resulted in four federal grants (2 NSF and 2 ONR), two internal grants for the commercialization of research outcomes, twenty-five peer-reviewed conference papers, and ten peer reviwed journal papers. In total, seven MS (thesis) and four PhD students are graduated by the three PIs during this grant period. Together the three PIs are currently supervising twenty graduate and five undergraduate research students. All of the recent graduates and current students of the PIs are the direct beneficiary of this grant.   Several local companies and small business entities for academy-industry collaboration and SBIR/STTR projects are using the testbed developed by this project. The PIs are also involved with the Kansas City STEM Alliance, which is a not-for-profit collaborative network of educators, businesses and related organizations working to inspire interest in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math with the mission of generating a robust workforce of related professionals for the greater Kansas City region.
